heading: doj tries to keep adult tv fuzzy
subheading: having lost its case against playboy, the department of justice attempts to keep other purveyors of adult content from beaming scrambled signals when kids might be channel surfing. by polly sprenger.
author: polly sprenger
text: two weeks after losing a landmark case against playboy enterprises, the department of justice is once again attempting to keep scrambled adult cable channels from broadcasting all day.on 28 december, playboy won the right to broadcast its adult television channel at any time of day or night.playboy argued that section 505 of the communications decency act of 1996 violated its right to free speech. that section, called "scrambling of sexually explicit adult video service programming," requires cable tv operators to either completely scramble sexually explicit programming or only air it between 10 p.m. and 6 a.m., when children are less likely to be tuning in.now, the justice department is back in court, arguing that the ruling only applies to playboy, and that other adult programming channels must still adhere to the 1996 act.in the 28 december ruling, the court allowed playboy to broadcast adult channels during daytime hours, but said the adult entertainment provider had to make a good faith effort to completely scramble its signal.previously, the justice department tried to argue that children could be affected by an incompletely scrambled program, because they could still catch brief glimpses of nudity, and hear the audio portion of the broadcast.technical hurdles prevent cable programmers from completely scrambling adult programming channels, relegating those channels to nighttime broadcasts only.the 28 december ruling stated that no clinical evidence exists to link viewing of pornography to psychological damage in children.the government is challenging the ruling in the us district court in delaware.
